metadata.title: Pressure Injuries  Prevention
anatomical location body part affected: Usually over a bony prominence (e.g., sacrum, ischial tuberosity, greater trochanter, heels, lateral malleolus, elbow); rarely on the head
description: Pressure or decubitus injuries are preventable adverse events

Pressure injuries are skin sores that develop because of sustained direct pressure or pressure combined with shear and/or friction on a contact or support surface. Poor hygiene, moisture, cold, or bacteria might predispose the skin microenvironment to pressure ulceration(1)

Pressure sores are a common health problem among individuals with limited mobility, especially those confined to bed or a wheelchair (e.g., patients in acute care units, older residents of nursing homes, persons with spinal cord injuries) Pressure injuries: prevention, evaluation, and management(35)
This Clinical Review focuses on prevention of avoidable pressure sores in patients at increased risk for their development
Prevention strategies typically involve reduction of the magnitude and/or duration of pressure between the patient and the contact surface and limiting exposure to moisture and bacteria

ICD-10 codes.L89.0: decubitus injury limited to erythema only [redness] without skin breakdown
ICD-10 codes.L89.1: decubitus injury limited to breakdown of skin
ICD-10 codes.L89.2: decubitus injury with fat layer exposed
ICD-10 codes.L89.3: decubitus injury with depth involving muscle
ICD-10 codes.L89.4: decubitus injury with depth involving bone
ICD-10 codes.L89.5: decubitus injury with joint space involvement
ICD-10 codes.L89.8: decubitus injury with necrosis involving muscle or bone
ICD-10 codes.L89.9: decubitus injury without mention of severity (ICD codes are provided for readers’ reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: Uniformity for coding and billing is lacking for services to prevent pressure injuries. The billing provider and reimbursing payer should be aware of the range of treatment services available; interventions that might be required for proper injury care and prevention will vary depending on unique patient needs(3)

Pressure injuries acquired during hospitalization that are evaluated as either stage III or IV (see Pathogenesis, below) are considered among 8 preventable conditions that have been identified by the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS). Since 2008,  hospitals no longer receive higher Medicare payments related to the injury-specific  care of patients who acquire stage III or IV pressure injury during their inpatient stay, as this is thought to be tantamount to allowing increased billing for inadequate preventive care. Private insurers are also adopting these reimbursement restrictions(25)

causes: Sustained mechanical deformation of skin and underlying tissues that restricts microvascular circulation; i.e., exceedscapillary closure pressure (32 mmHg or 4.27 kPa) in the contact area(4)
Lack of sensation to detect discomfort/pain at contact area and alleviate pressure
Inability of patient to relieve pressure on the affected body part because of immobility
Failure of staff to reposition immobile patient on a regular schedule (iatrogenic cause)
pathogenesis: Staging of the pressure injury by extent of tissue breakdown and necrosis based on initial examination(1)–Stage I: Intact skin with nonblanchable erythema. (Discoloration of the skin, warmth, edema, and induration, might beused as indicators in persons with darker skin)–Stage II: Partial thickness skin loss of epidermis, possibly including dermis; might involve abrasion, opened blister, orshallow crater–Stage III: Full-thickness  skin loss into subcutaneous tissue, with exposed fat–Stage IV: Involvement of deep subcutaneous tissue (below deep fascia), with damage to muscle; necrosis, undermining,and sinus tracts might be present–Stage V: Involvement of bone or joint space; necrosis usually present
In stage I pressure injuries, maximal cutaneous vasodilation offsets pressure-induced  capillary closure, resulting inerythema

Subcutaneous/deep sores can develop without evidence of skin ulceration; therefore, it is theorized that all pressure injuriesmight begin with some amount of deep tissue injury,(5) especially when the external deformation pressure is high(6)

Two proposed pathophysiological mechanisms of deep pressure injuries(6)–Ischemia – reversible biochemical changes (e.g., tissue hypoxia/hypoglycemia) that slowly lead to necrosis–Deformation – irreversible morphological changes that rapidly lead to necrosis
Stage III and IV sores often become chronic wounds with serious complications that include cellulitis, osteomyelitis,sepsis, and even death
risk factors: Extrinsic factors(35)–Increased pressure, friction/shear on skin–Excess moisture (incontinence, sweating) on skin–Elevated temperature (fever, reduced air contact with skin)–Chemical irritants

Intrinsic factors(35)–Impaired mobility–Sensory deficit (e.g., peripheral neuropathy)–Advanced age–Dry skin–Poor oxygen delivery to skin (anemia, peripheral vascular disease [PVD], congestive heart disease)–Malnutrition/nutritional deficiency (dehydration; insufficient intake of calories, vitamins, and protein; dysphagia/swallowing problems)–Inability to report problem (dementia, language barrier)–Comorbidities such as dementia, hypothyroidism, PVD (associated with ischemic ulcers), or diabetes (associated withdiabetic ulcers)–Postoperative immobilization (e.g., bed rest or plaster cast after lower extremity fracture)–Obesity/high BMI is an independent risk factor, but authors of a study in the United States found that including BMI didnot enhance the accuracy of the Braden scale for predicting pressure injuries(23)
Commonly used risk-assessment  instruments, such as the Braden, Norton, or Waterlow scales, can help identify patients atincreased risk for injuries(34)
There is limited evidence that use of risk-assessment  instruments is effective for reducing the incidence or severity ofpressure injuries(34)

Authors of a study of acutely ill military veterans (N = 213) in the United States found that 4 medical factors (malnutrition,pneumonia/pneumonitis, candidiasis, and surgery) had stronger predictive value (sensitivity 83%, specificity 72%) forpredicting pressure sores than the Braden Scale (sensitivity 65%, specificity 70%)(8)

Authors of a 2009 systematic review of 7 studies (only 3 considered of high quality) found that the interrater agreementfor total score on the Waterlow Scale was reliable and comparable to values reported for other pressure sore risk scales.(9)In contrast, authors of a 2011 literature review concluded that the Waterlow Scale was unreliable and had poor interraterreliability in all studies(10)

Risk factors based on the EQUIP Minimum Data Set(11)–History of pressure injury–Comatose–Male–Age over 65 years–Assistance in bed mobility–Assistance in transfers–Bedfast all or most of time–Bowel incontinence–Catheter or ostomy–Diabetes, PVD, or missing limb–MS or paraplegia–Clostridium difficile infection–Edema–End-stage  disease (not expected to live longer than 6 months)Guidelines for Pressure Injury Prevention
risk assessment: Assessment of modifiable risk factors includes:(25)–How frequently is the patient turned?–Is a skin inspection completed every shift?–Is the skin kept dry?–Is a pressure redistribution surface used?–If a nonexpanding device is used (e.g., orthotic device, splint), was it assessed and readjusted for fit?–Was patient education provided?

Assessment of nonmodifiable risk factors includes the following:(25)–Any risk associated with medically required treatment: poor tissue perfusion; continual wet tissue; unexpandable medicaldevice–Any risks related to pathophysiology: inability to turn (e.g., hemodynamic instability, respiratory instability, unstablespine); continually wet tissue (e.g., weeping wounds, uncontrollable body secretions); high-risk  tissue (e.g., poornutritional status, vascular insufficiency); inability to use pressure redistribution device due to other conditions (e.g.,unstable spine or pelvis)–Any risks associated with behavior: inability to decrease pressure on at-risk area(s) (e.g., psychiatric noncompliance,behavior by neurologically impaired patient)
A comprehensive skin assessment should be part of every risk assessment(26)
preventive skin care: Skin should be kept clean and dry, and moisturized as indicated
nutrition: Assessment should include weight history, ability to eat independently, and the adequacy of nutrient intake
Patients should also be monitored for signs of dehydration
repositioning and early mobilization gui: All patients at risk of or with existing pressure injuries should be repositioned regularly unless contraindicated–Repositioning frequency is determined by the individual’s tissue tolerance, level of activity and mobility, general medicalcondition, overall treatment objectives, skin condition, and comfort
Repositioning techniques should be used that avoid positioning over bony prominences and avoid subjecting skin tofriction and shear forces
Encourage patients who can reposition themselves to do so–Discourage bed positions that increase pressure such as semirecumbent

In repositioning seated individuals, provide adequate seat tilt to prevent sliding forward in the wheelchair or chair andadjust footrests and armrests to maintain proper posture and pressure redistribution
support surfaces: Pressure-redistributing  support surfaces are designed to either increase the body surface area that comes in contact with thesupport surface or to sequentially alter the parts of the body that bear load, thereby reducing the duration of loading on anygiven body part(26)

The National Pressure Ulcer Advisory Panel (NPUAP) guidelines provide an objective means for evaluating andcomparing support-surface  characteristics. NPUAP coordinates the development of uniform terminology, testing methods,and standards for reporting characteristics of support surfaces(7)
The appropriateness and functionality of the support surface should be examined at every encounter with the individual(26)

Selection of a support surface should meet the individual’s needs and take into consideration the following factors:(26)–Level of immobility and inactivity–Size and weight of the individual–Risk for development of new pressure injuries, and existence, severity, and location of current injuries–Need for microclimate control and shear reduction
Complete training on use and maintenance of seating support surfaces (including wheelchairs) and cushion devices shouldbe provided for both patient and caregiver(26)

overall contraindications precautions: Patients at risk for the development of pressure injuries will require careful monitoring of skin integrity on a regular basis; refer to medical team as concerns arise
See specific  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/Plan of Care

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Pressure sores are likely caused (or worsened) by external compression forces, shear forces, friction, moisture, and chemical irritants in persons at risk.(4) See Causes , pathogenesis , & risk factors , above, for more details Course of treatment  (7)Consists largely of pressure relief (through various mediums), nutrition therapy, and wound care through proper dressings, debridement, and cleansing (as indicated) -optimizing regional blood flow with a stent or vascular bypass surgery -surveillance and management of underlying illnesses (e.g., PVD, diabetes, hypothyroidism, metabolic syndrome, congestive heart failure, MS) -provision of adequate caloric and protein intakeIf patient has developed a pressure injury, topical phenytoin, oxyquinoline, becaplermin, or nerve growth factor might be prescribed -Medications that cause sedation or drying of the skin can increase the risk of pressure injuriesA bone scan might be completed to rule out osteomyelitisDocument whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions. In particular, note what education the patient has received pertaining to pressure injurie prevention, skin inspection, and use of pressure-reducing  devices and support surfaces
history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Document patient-specific factors (see Causes , pathogenesis, & risk factors ) that might place a patient at increased risk for acquiring pressure injuries
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (constant vs intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling). Inquire about pain, tenderness, and itchiness, which are common symptoms of early pressure injuries
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much). Use FLACC scale for children. Scales that can be used for nonverbal adults include the Critical Care Pain Observation Tool (CPOT) and the Pain Behavior Scale, both for critically ill adults(27)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night. Document position patient sleeps in, number of pillows used, type of mattress, areas of pressure
history of present illness.other symptoms: Systemic signs of infection Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning Yes __ No _____________________________ (Patient might have cognitive or language barrier)

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Document prior history of pressure sores or other skin conditions, if applicable. Document prior history of the condition that led to immobility and risk of pressure injury
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Document coexisting conditions (e.g., diabetes mellitus, anemia, fever, PVD, congestive heart disease, dehydration, SCI, MS, dementia, or other predisposing factors). Has the patient had any recent surgeries, fractures, or injuries?
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient/caregiver about other symptoms patient might be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Patient might spend a significant amount of time in bed or in a wheelchair -For injury prevention and management to be effective it is important to accurately identify and correct causative factors. The author of a case series of 45 patients who developed skin injuries on the medial buttocks and/or posterior thighs concluded that since the lesions were not located over palpable bony prominences they were unlikely to be pressure injuries and were most likely caused by friction damage to the skin, related to associated repetitive behaviors(29)
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Inquire about limitations. Patient might be bed or wheelchair bound -If patient is wheelchair bound (e.g., spinal cord injury), what pressure-relieving  procedures and maneuvers does he or she currently employ? What kind of wheelchair cushion is in use?
social and occupational history.living environment: Stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives (e.g., caregivers, family members). Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary? Are caregivers aware of the patient’s increased risk for pressure sores? Are caregivers able to assist patient in and out of various chairs at home, or does patient generally sit in one chair throughout the day? In what type of chair does patient typically sit? Is it adjustable? -Issues pertaining to domestic seating in community-dwelling  patients are often overlooked(30) -Number and timing of position changes might be dependent upon caregiver’s schedule or authorized home-health visits -Repositioning might require caregiver’s discipline and commitment -Inappropriate furniture (e.g., seating that is too high or too low) that is the patient’s property might be difficult to correct -Appropriate pressure-relieving  cushions to insert into furniture, such as recliners, might be difficult to find due to issues such as armrest height and seat height

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assistive and adaptive devices –Assess need for assistive device if gait or balance deficits are noted –Assess fit of orthosis or prosthesis, if applicable –If the patient uses a wheelchair, is the seating system appropriate for preventing the development of a pressure sore? –If patient is confined to bed, are devices available to assist mobility and relieve pressure? –Does the patient have appropriate pressure-relieving  cushions and/or mattresses?
relevant tests and measures.balance: Assess static and dynamic sitting/standing balance, as indicated
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Assess distal pulses, especially in patients with known vascular insufficiency or diabetesEvaluation of caregiver ergonomics and body mechanics might be appropriate in cases in which the patient requires physical assistance. Inappropriate body mechanics can increase the difficulty of transfers and mobility assistance for the caregiver to the point that moving the patient is avoidedAssess need for physical assistance, safety awareness during bed mobility/ transfers/wheelchair mobility, and need for adaptive equipment. Is the patient able to transfer or is the caregiver able to transfer the patient without causing shearing forces to body?
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Assess for gait deficits, need for assistive device, need for physical assistance, and cues for safety awareness, as indicated; assess mobility with wheelchair as indicated
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Manual muscle test (MMT) as indicated, or observe strength with functional activities. If the patient uses a wheelchair, is strength sufficient to unweigh body for pressure relief?
observation inspection palpation includi: Inspect and palpate skin for nonblanchable localized redness (or discoloration in dark-skinned  patients); warm, firm, or boggy skin tissue; skin breakdown with drainage
Measure and stage any wounds as they appear
Is a positioning schedule indicated (patients who are dependent on others for pressure relief)?
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess ROM/flexibility as indicated to allow for optimal sitting posture and to assess for contracturesIs the patient able to clean him-  or herself properly after voiding?
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Conduct a general screening for sensory deficits, especially over bony prominences
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosis –Braden Scale(8) –Waterlow Scale(9,10) –EQUIP-for-Quality  Risk Score(11)
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Assess arousal and orientation to name, time, place, and situation –The Mini Mental Status Examination (MMSE) might be used to screen for cognitive impairments –Dementia increases the risk for pressure injuries –Patients with impaired communication are at risk due to inability to report discomfort or pain adequately

contraindications precautions: Stimulation through or across the chest
Used in close proximity to diathermy treatment
Any time active contraction is contraindicated
other: Patients with a diagnosis of pressure injury might be at risk for falls due to functional decline; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention  instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention  strategies

The electrotherapy contraindications/precautions listed below are meant to serve as a guide (in some cases, with prior approval of the treating physician , electrotherapy might be used under some of the circumstances listed below when benefits outweigh the perceived risk)(33)

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Increased risk for pressure injuries due to confinement in a bed or wheelchair, illness, or functional decline and/or use of orthosis/prosthesis
prognosis: Healing time of a pressure injury is variable according to stage; might take weeks to months, or never heal(7)

Authors of a study (N = 1112) in the United States found that an early mobilization program (EMP) in a surgical critical care unit did not decrease the risk of hospital-acquired  pressure injuries(12)  –Based on a comparison of 555 patients who were admitted before implementation of the EMP and 557 patients admitted post implementation –EMP consisted of ROM, elevating head of bed, continuous lateral rotation, chair position, dangling, standing, and walking –5.4% of the pre-EMP  group developed pressure injuries versus 5.5% of the post-implementation  group
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Dietitian for nutrition assessment and/or management(13) Seating specialist for assessment and prescription of cushions for wheelchair users Occupational therapy, as indicated Physician or medical team if wound is present Nursing or wound care clinic for wound care Social services for equipment and home needs
other considerations: Subepidermal moisture (SEM), as a measure of localized edema, has been investigated for its ability to differentiate between healthy skin and skin with pressure-induced tissue damage.(31)An SEM scanning device,designed to be used by healthcare professionals, measures subepidermal electrical capacitance by applying low-frequency  electrical current(31) –Authors of a study conducted in the United States suggest that an SEM scanner shows promise as an objective, reliable device for detecting presence or absence of pressure-induced  tissue damage –Thirty-one  volunteers without pressure injuries or broken skin were assessed using the scanner -Three different operators used 4 different devices at 4 different anatomical sites (sternum, sacrum, heels) –Interoperator and interdevice reliability was good at all anatomical sites
treatment summary: Support surfaces that reduce tissue loading in bedridden patients include pressure-relieving  beds, mattresses, and overlays(2) –Higher specification foam mattresses might reduce the incidence of pressure injuries in persons at risk compared to the standard hospital foam mattress –The effectiveness of alternating pressure mattresses compared to constant low-pressure  surfaces is unclear(2) -Based on a systematic review of 53 RCT(2) –Researchers in the United Kingdom found no clear difference in the incidence of pressure sores between an alternating pressure mattress and an alternating pressure overlay, which can be obtained at a significantly lower price(14) –Pressure-relieving  overlay on the operating table might prevent postoperative pressure injuries –Medical-grade  sheepskins are associated with reduced incidence of pressure injuries –Authors of a 2014 systematic review found that high-quality  trial evidence is lacking to support the routine use of heel devices to prevent heel pressure injuries(24)

In a clinical practice guideline developed in the United Kingdom for prevention of pressure injuries, researchers reviewed the following seating concerns:(15) –Correct seated posture: height, depth, and width of the seat, backrest height, angle between seat and back of the chair, and design of armrests –Assessment of seating for the long-term  seated patient: e.g., cognitive ability, level of independence, posture, ability to relieve pressure, interface pressure, moisture and temperature of the seat interface, ability to transfer, deficits in sensation, continence management, comfort, method of wheelchair propulsion, previous use of cushions –Self-repositioning  methods: e.g., roll, forward lean, lift-off –Provision of seats, wheelchairs, and cushions –Types of cushions

Neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES): potential benefits –In theory, NMES might provide periodic relief of intramuscular deformation caused by external pressure and thereby increase tissue oxygenation(16) –Authors of a study in the United States found that surface electrical stimulation below the motor threshold intensity necessary for a contractile response of the gluteus maximus did not alter gluteal oxygenation or pressure distribution in adult men (N = 6) with SCI(17)
Evidence is lacking on the prevention of pressure sores after SCI(18)
Authors of a 2015 review of the literature found that evidence is lacking to support the use of massage to prevent pressure injuries(19)
Regular physical inspection of high-risk  areas might facilitate early detection

Patient education –Authors of an RCT (N = 41) in the United States found that individualized education and monthly telephone follow-up reduced the incidence of delayed pressure injury recurrence in men with SCIs who had pressure injury surgery(20) –An author of a study (N = 15) in the United States found that an interactive e-learning  program improved knowledge and skin care management in patients with recent SCI after discharge to home(21)

Bedding: silk-like  textile bed sheets might reduce the risk of developing pressure injuries –Authors of an RCT (N = 46) in the United States compared the rate of nursing-home-acquired  pressure injuries over 20 weeks in 2 groups(22) -Twenty-six  residents had silk-like  bedding and 20 residents had usual plain-weave  cotton/polyester bed sheets -The numbers of total and new non-stage  I ulcers were significantly lower in the group with silk-like  bedding

Prophylactic dressing might help prevent pressure injuries in critically ill ICU patients(32) –Based on a large RCT in Australia that involved 313 patients –Soft silicone multiple layer dressings were applied to the sacrum and heels of the intervention group on admission to the emergency department and maintained throughout the patient’s stay in ICU –Compared to the control group, incidence of both sacral and heel pressure injuries was significantly reduced in the intervention group . prevention of pressure injuries: Skin inspection with use of staging criteria
Risk assessment tools such as the Braden Scale or EQUIP-for-Quality  Risk Score
Presence or absence of new pressure injuries
Improved patient knowledge of pressure injury prevention and skin care management

maintenance or prevention: Patients at risk for pressure injuries should have regular skin management care
Prevention might require complete off-loading  of an injury at high risk of progression
